DOC.brief_summary: We wish to investigate whether a weekly, 2½ hour group-based osteoporosis education intervention (the Osteoporosis Prevention and Self-Management Course), is different to one session course (1x 2½ hours) on osteoporosis knowledge, confidence to eat calcium-containing foods, confidence to exercise, and amount of exercise undertaken after three and nine months of follow-up in people aged over 50 years who have already had a bone fracture.
DOC.brief_title: Education for Osteoporosis in Persons With Existing Fractures
DOC.detailed_description: Instruments used to determine change after 3 and 9 months: Osteoporosis knowledge: Osteoporosis Knowledge Assessment Test (Winzenberg et al. BMC Musculoskelet Disord 2003) Calcium intake: Food frequency questionnaire (Angus et al. J Am Diet Assoc 1989) Calcium and exercise self-efficacy: Osteoporosis Self-Efficacy Scale (Horan et al Res Nurs Health 1998) Physical activity: CHAMPS II (Stewart et al. J Gerontol A Biol Sci Med Sci 2001)
DOC.criteria: Presented to Modbury Hospital's Accident and Emergency Department with a new bone fracture Residence in nursing home Fracture sustained in motor bike, push bike or motor vehicle accident Fracture sustained due to high trauma, such as fall from roof or ladder Dementia Inability to participate in group settings Inability to understand spoken English Inability to provide informed consent Pathological fracture Usual place of residence outside South Australia
